text: hello everyone thank you so much for coming uh I may have been singing quite
loudly along with the line Breakers last night so my voice seems to be suffering a little bit this morning so apologies
in advance if it disappears halfway through this talk um but yeah thank you
so much for being here my name is Joe Franti and I am a developer Advocate
currently fun employed so uh if you enjoy this talk consider hiring
me um today I would like to talk to you about the importance of developer
experience so let's start with a story to illustrate what developer experience
actually is so you are a software developer and you've been asked to
integrate with a new developer tool let's call it kod magig and someone that you work with has
told you that kod magig has been recommended for its Advanced features and its timesaving
capabilities and you're excited about the potential that kod magig offers so you Embark upon the Journey of
onboarding with kod magig and you start with the obvious thing you open up your
favorite search engine and you try and find online tutorials and documentation
to understand the basics of cod magic however you quickly realize that there
aren't actually very many available resources and the ones that are avail ailable are quite poorly structured the
official documentation is incomplete it's outdated in places it lacks clear
examples and it doesn't give you good use cases and you have found some
tutorials but they're either overly simplified or they're over complicated and they skip over steps and it leaves
you feeling frustrated but you're determined to overcome this setback so
you reach out to the Cod Mig commity to get some assistance you join their online Forum their Discord and you hope
that you can find guidance from their experienced users but unfortunately the
community turns out to be quite unresponsive and also unwelcoming to newcomers so your questions go
unanswered for weeks but you're a consument professional you decide that
you don't need the community you can experiment with this code yourself you're going to work on a small project
but you quickly discover there's a very steep learning curve the code base is complex it lacks structure and it's just
challenging to navigate and find out the features of this tool it doesn't have
proper error handling it doesn't have good test coverage and you get these sort of cryptic error messages that
don't help you to understand what is happening when you're troubleshooting
you find lots of bugs and inconsistencies with the tool and being The Helpful community developer that you
are you report these back to Cod magig but you get no response your issue just
sits there untouched for days and as the weeks turn into months
your enthusiasm for COD magig wains and you start to question why the decision
has been made to use this tool it lacks learning resources it has
an unhelpful Community it has inherent flaws and it's just frustrating and demoralizing to use you decide that
despite all these promising features kod magig has such a poor
developer experience a lack of support and technical issues it's just impossible to use it's impossible to
fully leverage ultimately you and your team decide to abandon code ofama jig and go with a different tool alog
together one that offers better documentation Better Community Support and a much shallower learning curve so
we say byebye to Cod magig you have lost a customer because of your poor
developer experience and I'm sure a lot of you have experienced this kind of on
onboarding Journey with tools this experience with a new be it a new tool a
framework a language is going to this first experience that you have is going to be
the deciding factor of whether or not you continue to use this whether you decide to become an advocate for it and
convince other people that they enjoy it and it's going to sway developers as to
how they experience the quality of the products that you're building and developer experience or DX as it's often
written oh gosh my voice is going already describes the journey that a developer takes as they on board and use
your code it's the lived experience of developers and the points of friction
that they encounter as they work with the things that you are writing and developer experience isn't
just at that getting started stage it goes all all the way through building
testing debugging releasing products with the things that you're writing and as developers who are
writing code even if you do manage to get someone to onboard onto your
product the tools that you're building have to have a pleasant developer experience or you're going to lose them
in the future the moment they see something that looks better that has better support that's easier to work
with they are going to jump ship poor developer experience will cost you money it'll ruin your customer base and damage
your reputation and a common misconception is that devx is only you know the tools
themselves or the products themselves but research shows that there are actually human factors involved as well
so things like having clear goals having easy stepbystep guides feeling like you
psychologically are competent and can deal with this code base can make a huge
differ to the developer experience so let's take a deeper dive
into what can affect developer experience then I'll give some examples of how we can measure developer
experience and then I'll give some examples of things that I've seen out in the wild that I think that we can
improve so there was a recently released paper by the Association for computing
Machinery on developer productivity and they break down this idea of developer
experience into three segments so we have cognitive load we have Flow State and we have feedback loops and when we
consider these all together these three factors describe the full range of friction types that can be encountered
by developers as they work with your code so let's take a brief look at each
of these as I'm sure you're all aware software development can sometimes be
quite difficult it's complex it's complicated there always new tools new
languages new Frameworks new methodologies to learn and writing and
reading and learning code all contribute to a workload in your brain and this is
called the cognitive load and cognitive load refers to how much information a
developer requires in order to process a task in order to complete a task
alongside how much other stuff is happening at the same time in their heads so it's how much effort it's going
to take them to learn and to retain information and psychologists often
refer to this as something called The Working memory uh and it's how much capacity your brain has to hold
information temporarily and it actually works very similar to how the Ram in
your computer works so you have a certain amount of Fast Access Storage which you start to fill up as you're
doing tasks and at some point your cognitive capacity will be full and you will either have to stop doing something
or forget about something when you want to do something new or you're going to start to make mistakes you're going to
start to see errors occurring and you'll find yourself slowing down the more
things you try and pick up and cognitive load increases as the things that we're
doing become more difficult or more complex uh so things like learning
something completely new takes quite a lot of cognitive load but it can also be
increased by extraneous information processing while we're trying to do a task so unfortunately things like trying
to multitask actually can massively increase our cognitive load uh working
in a noisy environment or working with a lot of different things happening on your screen at once can all increase
your cognitive load or if people are asking you to switch tasks so you're constantly holding something in short
shortterm memory things like poor documentation where you're searching and
trying to get through a lot of different things at once too much instruction Too Little Instruction badly designed tasks
that don't allow you to flow from one step to another these can all affect your cognitive load and feeling anxious
or feeling bored or if you're over tired these can all decrease your um the
working memory that you have available and there for increase the cognitive
load and when cognitive load is high you're going to have to put a lot more effort into retaining the information
that you're reading a lot more effort into achieving the goals that you're trying to achieve and you're more likely
to make mistakes and you're less likely to be Innovative when your cognitive load is high so it's really important
that we consider this when we are coding when we are making tools we want to
improve the developer experience as much as possible to reduce the cognitive load on the developers that are using our
products we should be finding ways to eliminate unnecessary hurdles in the
process of onboarding developers we should be creating well organized code bases we should be creating uh great
documentation we should be making sure that we are setting easy tasks to follow
that are step by step and dedicated devx team teams can provide things like easy
to use self-service tools they can help streamline your documentation make sure that it's always
up to dat and of course this is not only for people who are on boarding but this
is for those who are well established as well and who are bug fixing who need things like useful error messages that
link to FAQs that kind of thing and consider presenting the
information that you're giving these developers to help them with onboarding in different forms uh people learn in
different ways and so presenting things like written documentation maybe a video
maybe a stepbystep guide maybe a fully-fledged demo that they can just
dive into and see the code these are all going to make your tool your code base
more accessible allow developers to use the tools that work best for them
because when cognitive load is well-managed developers find it much easier to be efficient and to be
productive and it allows for something called Flow State to happen and I'm sure
you've heard people say things like oh I'm really in the zone that idea of being in the zone is
when you are in Flow State and sometimes people will say like oh you know I was
just in the zone and then I had to jump into a meeting and that's when the flow state is has been interrupted and flow
state is a mental disposition where a person is fully immersed in the activity
that they're performing it feels really enjoyable being in Flow State it's quite
energizing you feel more creative you feel more productive you feel motivated
and you're actually more efficient when you're in Flow State you find it much easier to retain information much easier
to fix problems much easier to come up with innovative solutions and it's actually it's an
enjoyable feeling and it can lead developers to perform better and to produce better products so it stands to
reason that we want to create an environment that allows for Flow State so in order to do this there's a
few things that we can do firstly we need to make sure that the skill level
and the challenge that we're uh presenting are well balanced so tasks
should present enough of a challenge that the developer is interested their mind is engaged they're they're in a
problem solving space but they're not confused or frustrated they're not overwhelmed too much challenge can leave
you feeling belittled it can leave you feeling foolish and it can start a feeling of anxiety and you start to sort
of Scrabble and suddenly that flow is completely gone I remember once my dad called me
and he was like my computer's broken and I asked him well why didn't you just
like you have the entire internet at your disposal why didn't you look up a fix before you called me and his
response was if he spent say 2 hours Googling for a fix he might spend two
hours trying to fix his computer and at the end of it he wasn't sure whether he'd have a fixed computer or not his
skill level did not match the challenge that was in front of him but he knew if he called me and I looked up a fix I'd
probably be able to within the 2 hours find a fix fix the computer would know the computer was fixed he gave up before
he'd even started because his skill level was just not great enough to match the challenge and we want to be creating
confidence in developers that they're going to be able to use these tools to understand them to onboard and getting
this balance of Challenge and skill is when you really allow developers to feel like they're in control of the
process and we can do this so the the skill level um challenge balance we can
do this by setting clearly defined tasks and achievable goals as we're helping
them on board so you know we give them clear insallation steps we give them code demos so that they can you know
take it and run it and see something happen completing tasks gives a
developer a sense of achievement and makes them more likely to want to pick up the next task and the next
task and conversely things like interruptions and delays are going to hinder your Flow State so anytime you
struggle to find information you might find yourself sort of you know you need to swap from your IDE to your browser
and suddenly you've opened your browser and then you've seen that you've got an email and then you've responded to that email you've answered something on slack
you completely forgot what you were doing in your ID you have to go back and reimmerse yourself
we really don't want to be putting out these uh so the way I think of it is your your developers like a sprinter and
they're running on a sprinting track and every time you have a a problem like a
bug in your software or some documentation that doesn't explain something or an error message that
doesn't help them it's like you've just thrown a brick out in front of that Sprinter and they've tripped over it and
now they have to get back up again and start sprinting again and every time there's a brick it takes the more energy
to get back up again so we want to be removing These Bricks as fast as
possible switching between tasks getting lost and frustrated or distracted
reduces the focus the developer has and makes it more likely that they're just going to give up they're going to do
something else so if you've ever found yourself doing things like checking your email or
doing admin type tasks when you're over tired or when you're frustrated with a project or you've got a problem that
just you can't find an answer to it's because you don't want to face that mental hurdle you don't want to you
don't have the energy required to stand up after that brick and start sprinting
again a flow State absolutely depends on developers having the autonomy and the
opportunity to work on fulfilling challenges that give them tasks that they want to do next and the best way to
find out whether or not we're getting this Challenge and skill level right is by asking for feedback getting feedback
from the developers that are using our products and also giving feedback to them so that they know whether they're
whether they've done something right whether they have understood a task and so that brings us nicely onto feedback
loops and it feels like a really obvious thing to say but meaningful feedback loops between developers and uh
developer effort and and impact is is Central to developer experience how can
we know that we're doing a good job that we're creating a good developer experience without getting feedback from
the developers who are using our tools feedback allows us to find where we've made mistakes it allows us to learn and
improve and it Fosters a feeling of visibility amongst the developer community so if they're giving us
feedback and we're acting on it it makes them feel like we care about what they they think we care that they care about
our products and it will allow us to discover where developers are struggling
where we've accidentally put those bricks out and where their cognitive load is becoming too much and this is
ultimately going to lead us to build more beloved products which is what we want to do and we should also be looking
to provide feedback to developers while they're using our products getting feedback to them quickly while they're
working is absolutely imperative to maintaining that flow state I'm sure
this is something you've all felt yourselves when you have good test coverage for example and you get that
immediate green and you're like cool that's that I can move on to the next thing uh we should have things like
continuous integration so that they can run their tests and get working immediately without having to you know
open up a browser or or whatever it is uh they should be able to stay in their
IDE stay focused stay on task uh we can do things like offer
steps in the tutorial so that they can have a load of tick boxes so they can say cool I'm moving forwards I'm getting
through each thing providing slow feedback or no feedback will leave developers in the
dark it'll lead them to have increased cognitive load and a reduced Flow State
and feedback could be an entire talk in itself so if you're wanting to learn more there's actually a tiny little link
down at the bottom there and I will share these slides out at the end um but that's an excellent article by uh Tim
Cochran who's the technical director of thought Works who talks about feedback loops and how to implement
them so the Eternal question when we're talking about developer experience is
how do I know that I have made a difference how do I know that the changes that I made are
improvements and in order to know where you stand currently you need to be
measuring and then you can know whether or not you're making a positive change
and the question of what to actually measure with DX is a is a difficult one
and I hate to say it but the answer is kind of it depends uh DX encompasses so many
different aspects it's quite challenging to quantify but these are some common things that you can measure that I would
recommend you consider measuring so firstly get feedback as I've mentioned
already you can conduct surveys you can be checking your your GitHub for issues
and you can use these to understand customer satisfaction and whether your customers have any particular pain
points there's also things like net promoter score uh which will tell you whether or not your customers would
recommend you to somebody else and cessat which is the customer satisf action score which tells you how your
customers feel about the point that they decide to pay for your product so maybe they've moved from a free tier to a paid
tier like what were they thinking at that time why did they make that decision how is that going to help you
get more developers through that Pipeline and you can track your internal
team as well so do regular check-ins with your developers to give you an idea of where they think improvements can be
made in your internal teams and it's a really sad metric but also track
employee turnover um it's vital to get that information at exit interview if your
employees are leaving you need to know why and you need to know what isn't working for
them uh we can use code quality metrics such as code review feedback so this is
something you should be tracking uh things like code complexity code
coverage and you can even things like the numbers of bugs that are reported the numbers of GitHub issues that you
have and you want to track these over time to see if the DX changes that
you're making are you know having the desired effect hopefully reducing code complexity increasing code coverage
reducing the number of bugs and we can also we should also be thinking about
things like documentation quality here so evaluate how much your documentation
covers your code base uh how many demos you have uh how much comment how many
comments are there in your code uh regularly make sure that your
documentation is up to date and trim out any that is old or is
misleading and then we can do things like measure kpis we can measure burndown charts uh which is the number
of completed story points uh the number of features that you've managed to deliver over a period of time uh this
will help you understand about your team's productivity and whether or not they're struggling like whether your internal developer experience is
stopping your developers from being as productive as they could be and there's an absolutely incredible research paper
uh by cat Hicks and her team over at plural site which measures developer productivity and developer thriving and
I highly recommend that you check that out um it really talks about how we can
improve that internal developer experience and you can assess things
like communication within your team so how frequently are people in meetings
how many hours are they spending in meetings uh how much time do they have to spend on email are they getting
knocked out of the flow because they're constantly on email or they're constantly on slack get a good idea of
what times of day your developers are working and for how many hours it's a good indication that your developers
that your team might be heading towards burnout if you see them sending emails
or messages you know at nighttime or early in the morning and also measure
things like participation in training programs or certifications and skill
development make sure that your team is given the time to develop their skills
uh they don't want to be keeping their nose to the grindstone all day you know they have to be developing themselves as
well to feel like they are in an environment that cares about
them and then there's the development cycle itself so we can take time to see
how long it get how long it takes to get from an idea to building a product
shorter development Cycles usually imply a smoother development process so we
want to measure the time that is spent debugging versus building features uh we
can track how frequently uh code changes are deployed to production uh a high deployment
frequency suggests that we've got an efficient development and release process and remember that DX is
multifaceted you're going to have to consider a whole lot of quantitative and
qualitative metrics to get a full understanding of your DX and this is going to be very personal for each of
your own projects so you're going to have have to make some decisions about which of these metrics you need to
track but regularly collecting and analyzing these metrics is going to be
absolutely vital for making improvements you can't know whether you're doing the right things unless you're
measuring and the overarching goal of DX is to provide a smooth and efficient
environment for developers and DX I tend to think of it split into two separate
areas so on the one hand we have our internal developer experience so this is
the people that we work with directly who are on our teams who are working with us in the same company or on the
same project and on the other hand we have external developer experience so these are the developers that you may
never meet in person the ones who are using your products uh and it's
obviously going to be much easier for you to Define your internal DX because you know these people you can talk to
them your in external developer experience is going to require a lot
more research you're going to have to make some assumptions about who they are about who you want them to be who you
want to reach what their skill set is and then you can start to once you've got an idea of who they are provide the
right guidelines for them the right steps the right improvements and of course you're all
going to interpretate the information in this talk and make it relevant for your own teams and products but I'd like to also
give you some practical takeaways and these are things that I've seen that I think reduce cognitive load and help
keep developers in the zone so we're going to start with the absolute Basics so we'll start with our code
bases so these are some standard hygiene practices that seem obvious when you see
them written out like this but I have seen some things out there and so we're
going to go over each one and talk about how it can make a difference to your
developer experience so firstly a good codebase
follows the default language Convention of the language that you are working in at the time and anything that deviates
from these standards no matter how clever you think you're being or how well-intentioned you are it's going to
increase the cognitive load on the developer every change that you make from the standard you're just putting
more bricks out in front of your Sprinter there's going to be surprises for them
and remember also that every new tool that you include every dependency that you include you're just raising that bar
to entry again it's another thing for them to learn it's another little brick for them to potentially trip
over uh I may be preaching to the choir here but you can reduce time spent on
boarding by making use of Dev containers and code spaces uh and if you aren't
familiar with with them containers are lightweight packages that contain your entire application code together with
its dependencies and they create a full developer environment with minimal setup
so your developers will no longer need complicated dependency installation or
fears about platform compatibility uh GitHub offers code spaces that you can run uh either in uh
the browser or in vs code and vs code has a containers extension as well so
you can use a container as your full-time development environment which just allows developers to get started so
much quicker taking those bricks away and if you can't use a Dev
container please at least try and avoid Global dependencies if you can it just
makes it that bit easier for developers to reproduce your projects uh and it
helps maintain the integrity and the stability across different setups I'm a window those user I fall foul of this
all the time and if you can't uh avoid external dependencies then please
consider scripting them so uh for your JavaScript users you can put some
scripts in your uh package Json and then execute them with Yar or mpm and these
scripts are going to run those global dependencies uh installations for you
but remember the gotcha again these commands will differ between
uh Mac and windows so please consider us Windows users we love
you the next thing to talk about is you read me um it serves as the initial
point of contact for any developers who are using your code it's their
introduction to you as a developer it's their introduction to how you think to why you built this to why you care about
it it's their introduction to you as a writer and a human it helps them to
understand what your project is about uh why you built it why they should be interested in it and a well-crafted
readme can massively improve the developer experience enhance the accessibility the usability of your
products so invest time in writing a comprehensive read me it might feel like
an annoyance you know you you finished your project now you're ready to release it and now you've got to write an essay
about why you made it like but it helps communicate the value of your the thing
that you've built and it helps to Foster engagement so these are a few things
that I want to see when I uh open a new project and look at its readme so first
up if the readme is long I really appreciate a table of contents at the top so that I can jump to where I need
to be um there are generators online to make these contents for you vs code also
has an extension that'll make it for you based on your headings uh start the read me with a
brief brief introduction to your project so describe its purpose what the goals are what the key features are and then I
want to know how to use your project so what do I need in order to run it uh for
example what version of node do I need how do I build it how do I run it give
me some nice commands that I can just copy and paste as code Snippets uh so
that I can get going immediately really hold my hand through this give me
a usage guide provide instructions on how to use your project explain the main
functionalities and include code samples include usage scenarios and let me know if there is
any configuration needed uh give details on how I can configure how I can
customize and give me example configuration files again that I can just copy and paste give me actual code
Snippets of the configuration with a you know your ID here or whatever it
is let me know the Project's constraints so are there any particular gchas are there any bricks that I should look out
for because if I know about them ahead of time I can just jump over them don't leave me guessing about why you made the
decisions that you made in this project and there are other things that you can also add to your read me or you
can add them as separate um markdown documents so guidelines for contribution
are really important we want developers to be engaging we want them to be giving
us feedback so explain how they can contribute how they run the tests how
you want bug reports submitted how they can propose enhancements uh any specifically
required coding styles that you expect any linting rules you expect them to follow any testing Frameworks that
you're using make it as easy as possible for contributions and you will get
them uh provide contact details so if they find something but they don't want
to make a contribution how can they contact you and ask you about it how can they get help from your
community uh make sure you include a code of conduct and this will
explain the behavior that you expect from your community and the behavior that you expect from the people who are
contributing and what will happen if there is a violation of that code of conduct so how you're going to handle it
and also uh any restrictions or requirements of using modifying or Distributing your code should be in a
licensed document and a well-written read me as you said just massively
improves the clarity the usability the overall quality of your project and just
really is going to help improve that developer experience experience good technical writing can
make a huge difference to your read me to your documentation to your tutorials uh to your blog
posts what you're doing with technical writing is you're taking what is quite a complex topic and you're breaking it
down making it accessible making it digestible and an important content of
good component sorry of good technical writing is understanding who you're
writing for so getting to know your audience uh start the writing process before you even start writing consider
who the reader is so what is their technical expertise what is their um
what is their role and their responsibility are they beginners are they experts once you've identified who
they are maybe consider creating a persona for them so you know this is
Fred Fred is a CTO this is George George is a beginner developer and what those
people want from the documentation is going to be different you know the CTO wants to know why this product exists
and why they're being made to pay for it and George wants to know uh how he can
fix this bug that he's found assign them a whole background a
name a story an understanding of why they're reading this document and then
when you're writing you can write with them in mind make sure that you're using using simple direct language that is going to
convey your message as clearly and concisely as possible keep a consistent tone of voice consistent use of tenses I
know this all feels obvious but I have seen the readmes that are out there um
write low complexity sentences uh keep your vocabulary low complexity as well
keep your paragraph short give frequent examples focus on readability and
accessibility so use things like headings to convey the hierarchy of the
document use descriptive link text uh
and of course give your images descriptive alt text as well uh use inclusive language so think
about the ability specific language that you're using and I see this a lot um use
things like read instead of see or check out instead of look at and try not to
refer to things as crazy or dumb try wild or
baffling there's no need to be using aess language to be using gendered
language in your writing we have a bunch of uh neutral pronouns that we can use
uh we can use things like um work hours instead of man hours or Staffing instead
of Manning and avoid things like idioms or slang when you're writing because these
can confuse people whose first language isn't the same language that you are writing in and try and avoid as much as
possible saying that a step is easy or that it's simple like oh simply do this or you can easily do this if the
developer then has a problem following that simple step that easy step they feel belittled they feel
like they've Fallen at the first brick basically and they're just going to get up turn around so uh don't make them
feel belittled many of us have a short attention span these days I know I
certainly do big chunks of text if I see a big wall of text my brain just slides
off it like Teflon so try and uh break up big walls of text with uh
illustrations with Graphics that are going to um add to your point point and
this also helps engage people who don't connect well with written words who
would rather learn through pictures through um diagrams much of your audience might be
visual Learners so accommodate these people with functional imagery and finally consider different learning
styles as I mentioned earlier so not everybody wants to read some people may want to watch a video or listen to audio
some people will want a step-by-step tutorial some people will want want a fully functional demo that they can just
look at the code they don't even want to read your step by step and the final thing that I want to
talk about today is the code itself so these are just a few things that I've seen that I think can make a difference
to your developer experience because we spend the majority of our time with code
reading it rather than writing it and we've all seen illegible code bases when
you're writing code that others are going to read it's really important that the code that you write is clear and
concise and get your point across you're writing it with an intention of somebody
else reading it and understanding it and this person who's reading it
you're likely not going to be able to get a chance to talk to them you're not going to be able to explain yourself
explain why you did these things so your code needs to be self-explanatory your code should be
unsurprising to the reader and lowering the cognitive load as much as possible allowing them to stay in that flow
state so first thing I like to see is functions without side effects functions
that do one thing and one thing only pure functions they're easier to read They're solely dependent on themselves
they're not going to affect any external State and it means by doing this that
your readers have less head compute they can look at that function they can say okay that function does that thing I Now
understand what that does I move on to to the next one I don't need to keep it in my head I don't need to keep thinking
about what this thing does functions with fewer arguments are generally easier to read and easier to
comprehend um and if you if you really struggle with this uh try and refactor
your functions to make them smaller so that you can reduce the amount of arguments when you look at a code base
that has you know a huge amount of arguments in in your um functions it
just again it immediately starts the the Panic sets in and you're like oh I've
got to remember all of these things I've got to understand what each of these things needs to do before I can understand what this function does
you're knocking that developer out of the Flow State promises are more readable than
callbacks uh so instead of nested callbacks try and use promises they make it easier to see the linear flow of
progression through your code and they result in more concise code blocks
they're just going to help the developers understand the flow of the asynchronous operations um and again
going to reduce the cognitive load if they can read your code and understand what is happening at each step it's
going to help them stay in the flow state for longer uh return early and often so
Place early return statements at the beginning of your functions or your methods this is going to immediately
communicate the conditions under which the function should exit so this again we're reducing the need
for the developer to hold things in their head they can understand okay it's going to exit here I don't even need to
read the rest of it or I need to read that next little bit and then it's going to exit there okay
great it minimizes the need for the dev to hold multiple conditional branches in
their heads while they're reading your code uh avoid the Pyramid of Shame so
nested if statements um as the nest ing level increases it's more convoluted it's more
difficult to follow what has happened they're much more likely to make mistakes there's much more likely to be a bug in your code it's harder to follow
the logic of what is happening um yeah pyramed shame leads to bugs maintenance
issues and increased cognitive load and try and use descriptive
language uh when you're naming your functions when uh instead of using a
